scenario:
Nu Holdings, a fintech company operating in Latin America, has a market cap of $55 billion and is trading at $12, 31% off its peak. The company's revenue rose 43% in 2024, with a compound annual growth rate of 32% estimated by Wall Street analysts for the next three years. Nu's digital banking platform has resonated with customers in Brazil, Mexico, and Colombia, with 114 million customers as of Dec. 31, more than twice the number from three years ago. The company's net profit margin increased from negative 9.7% in 2021 to 17% in 2024.

Key risks include effective risk management, as a loosening of lending standards could increase the probability of borrower defaults, and the company's growth rate may slow as it penetrates its core markets. Being based in Latin America also poses risks such as interest rate changes, inflationary pressures, and geopolitical turmoil.

Despite these risks, Nu's shares trade at a compelling valuation, with a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 19.4, in line with the S&P 500 index. The company's long-term prospects and scalability of its business model make it a solid stock to buy below $12 for long-term investors.
